canonical_explanation.text:
The neural system coordinates and integrates the functions of different organs and organ systems through electrical impulses. The human neural system is divided into the central nervous system (CNS — brain and spinal cord) and the peripheral nervous system (PNS — cranial and spinal nerves). The PNS is further divided into the somatic nervous system (voluntary) and the autonomic nervous system (involuntary), which includes the sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions. The neuron is the structural and functional unit of the nervous system. It consists of a cell body (soma), dendrites, and an axon. Neurons are classified as sensory (afferent), motor (efferent), and interneurons (association neurons). Myelinated nerve fibres have a myelin sheath with gaps called nodes of Ranvier, enabling saltatory conduction.

A nerve impulse is an electrochemical signal. The resting membrane potential (~-70 mV) is maintained by the Na⁺/K⁺ pump. When stimulated, Na⁺ channels open (depolarisation), creating an action potential that propagates along the axon. Repolarisation occurs when K⁺ channels open. At the synapse, neurotransmitters (e.g., acetylcholine) are released from synaptic vesicles to transmit the signal to the next neuron. The brain has three major parts: the forebrain (cerebrum, thalamus, hypothalamus), the midbrain, and the hindbrain (cerebellum, pons, medulla oblongata). The cerebrum is the largest part, responsible for higher mental functions. The cerebellum coordinates voluntary movements and maintains balance. The medulla controls involuntary functions like breathing and heart rate. The brain is protected by the cranium, meninges (three membranes), and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). A reflex arc is the neural pathway for a reflex action, involving a receptor, sensory neuron, integration centre (spinal cord), motor neuron, and effector. The eye and ear are important sense organs. The eye has photoreceptors (rods for dim light, cones for colour vision) on the retina. The ear is responsible for hearing (cochlea, organ of Corti) and balance (semicircular canals, vestibular apparatus).
rules: A neuron has three parts: cell body (soma with Nissl granules), dendrites (receive impulses), and axon (conducts impulses away from cell body).
Neurons are classified as sensory (afferent), motor (efferent), and interneurons (association); structurally as unipolar, bipolar, and multipolar.
Resting potential (~-70 mV) is maintained by the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump (3 Na⁺ out, 2 K⁺ in); the inside is negative relative to outside.
Action potential: stimulus → Na⁺ influx (depolarisation) → peak (+40 mV) → K⁺ efflux (repolarisation) → undershoot → resting potential restored.
Saltatory conduction occurs in myelinated fibres: the impulse jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next, increasing speed.
At a synapse, arrival of impulse → Ca²⁺ influx → synaptic vesicles release neurotransmitter → binds receptors on postsynaptic membrane → new impulse generated.

Brain: forebrain (cerebrum for higher functions, thalamus relays sensory info, hypothalamus controls body temperature/hunger/thirst), midbrain, hindbrain (cerebellum for balance, pons relays signals, medulla oblongata for vital involuntary functions).
Cerebrum has four lobes: frontal (motor, reasoning), parietal (sensory), temporal (auditory), occipital (visual); the cortex has grey matter, the interior has white matter.
Reflex arc: receptor → sensory neuron → spinal cord (integration centre) → motor neuron → effector (muscle/gland).
Eye: cornea → aqueous humour → pupil (iris controls) → lens (ciliary muscles for accommodation) → vitreous humour → retina (rods and cones) → optic nerve.
Rods contain rhodopsin (scotopsin + retinal), function in dim light; cones contain iodopsin, responsible for colour vision and function in bright light. The fovea has maximum cone density.
Ear: outer ear (pinna, ear canal) → middle ear (tympanic membrane, 3 ossicles: malleus, incus, stapes) → inner ear (cochlea with organ of Corti for hearing, semicircular canals for balance).

questions.question_text: The structural and functional unit of the nervous system is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The neuron (nerve cell) is the structural and functional unit of the nervous system. It is specialised for receiving stimuli and transmitting electrical impulses. Each neuron has a cell body, dendrites, and an axon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nephron is the structural unit of the kidney. Neuroglia are supporting cells of the nervous system but are not the functional unit. A nerve is a bundle of many neuron fibres, not a single unit.

questions.question_text: The part of the neuron that receives nerve impulses from other neurons is the:
questions.explanation_correct: Dendrites are short, branched cytoplasmic extensions of the neuron that receive nerve impulses from other neurons or from sensory receptors. They conduct impulses towards the cell body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The axon conducts impulses away from the cell body. The cell body (soma) contains the nucleus and is the metabolic centre. The synaptic knob (axon terminal) transmits impulses to the next neuron or effector.

questions.question_text: Nissl granules are found in the:

options.text: Cell body and dendrites of the neuron

questions.explanation_correct: Nissl granules (Nissl bodies) are composed of rough endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes. They are found in the cell body (soma) and dendrites of neurons but are absent from the axon and axon hillock. They are responsible for protein synthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nissl granules are absent from the axon. They are not restricted to dendrites only but are present in both the cell body and dendrites. The myelin sheath is a lipid-rich layer formed by Schwann cells and does not contain Nissl granules.

questions.question_text: The gaps between successive myelin sheath segments along a myelinated nerve fibre are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Nodes of Ranvier are the gaps between adjacent Schwann cells along a myelinated axon where the axon membrane is exposed. These nodes are essential for saltatory conduction, where the action potential jumps from node to node, greatly increasing conduction speed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Synapses are junctions between two neurons. Schwann cells are the glial cells that form the myelin sheath in the PNS. Neurilemma is the outer membrane of the Schwann cell. The gaps between myelin segments are specifically called nodes of Ranvier.

questions.question_text: The resting membrane potential of a neuron is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The resting membrane potential of a neuron is approximately -70 mV. This negative potential is maintained by the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump (which pumps 3 Na⁺ out and 2 K⁺ in) and the differential permeability of the membrane to various ions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: +40 mV is the approximate peak of an action potential during depolarisation. 0 mV is the threshold at which an action potential is triggered. -120 mV is too negative. The standard resting potential is about -70 mV.

questions.question_text: During the generation of an action potential, the rapid influx of which ion causes depolarisation of the neuron?
questions.explanation_correct: Depolarisation occurs when voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open, allowing a rapid influx of Na⁺ ions into the cell. This makes the inside of the membrane more positive, reversing the polarity from -70 mV towards +40 mV.
questions.explanation_incorrect: K⁺ efflux causes repolarisation, not depolarisation. Ca²⁺ is important at the synapse for neurotransmitter release but does not cause depolarisation of the axonal membrane. Cl⁻ influx would hyperpolarise the cell.

questions.question_text: Saltatory conduction of nerve impulses occurs in:
questions.explanation_correct: Saltatory conduction (from Latin 'saltare' meaning to jump) occurs in myelinated nerve fibres. The impulse jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next, as the myelin sheath insulates the internodal regions. This makes conduction faster and more energy-efficient compared to continuous conduction in non-myelinated fibres.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-myelinated fibres conduct impulses continuously along the entire length of the axon, which is slower. Dendrites and smooth muscle fibres do not exhibit saltatory conduction.

questions.question_text: At a chemical synapse, the neurotransmitter is released from the:

options.text: Cell body of the postsynaptic neuron
Synaptic knob (axon terminal) of the presynaptic neuron

questions.explanation_correct: At a chemical synapse, the nerve impulse reaches the synaptic knob (axon terminal) of the presynaptic neuron. Ca²⁺ ions enter, causing synaptic vesicles to fuse with the presynaptic membrane and release neurotransmitter into the synaptic cleft.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dendrites receive impulses but do not release neurotransmitter. The postsynaptic cell body receives the signal. Nodes of Ranvier are involved in saltatory conduction, not neurotransmitter release.

questions.question_text: The Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump maintains the resting potential by actively transporting:

options.text: Equal numbers of Na⁺ and K⁺ in both directions

questions.explanation_correct: The Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump actively transports 3 Na⁺ ions out of the cell and 2 K⁺ ions into the cell for each ATP molecule hydrolysed. This creates an electrochemical gradient with more positive charges outside, contributing to the negative resting potential inside the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pump moves Na⁺ out and K⁺ in, not the other way around. The ratio is 3:2 (not 2:3 or equal), which results in a net loss of positive charge from the cell, contributing to the negative resting potential.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes repolarisation during an action potential?

options.text: Na⁺ channels open and Na⁺ rushes into the cell
K⁺ channels open and K⁺ moves out of the cell, restoring negative potential
Ca²⁺ enters the axon from the extracellular fluid
Both Na⁺ and K⁺ move into the cell simultaneously

questions.explanation_correct: During repolarisation, voltage-gated Na⁺ channels close and voltage-gated K⁺ channels open. K⁺ ions flow out of the cell along their concentration gradient, making the inside of the membrane negative again and restoring the resting potential.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na⁺ channels opening causes depolarisation, not repolarisation. Ca²⁺ entry is relevant at the synapse, not during repolarisation of the axon. Simultaneous inward movement of both ions would not restore the resting potential.

questions.question_text: The correct sequence of events during synaptic transmission is:

options.text: Impulse arrives → Ca²⁺ influx → Vesicle fusion → Neurotransmitter release → Binding to receptors → Postsynaptic potential
Neurotransmitter release → Impulse arrives → Ca²⁺ influx → Binding to receptors
Ca²⁺ influx → Impulse arrives → Vesicle fusion → Postsynaptic potential
Binding to receptors → Neurotransmitter release → Ca²⁺ influx → Impulse arrives

questions.explanation_correct: The correct sequence is: (1) action potential arrives at the synaptic knob, (2) voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels open and Ca²⁺ enters the terminal, (3) Ca²⁺ triggers fusion of synaptic vesicles with the presynaptic membrane, (4) neurotransmitter is released into the synaptic cleft, (5) it binds to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane, (6) this generates a postsynaptic potential.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The impulse must arrive first before any other event. Neurotransmitter release cannot precede Ca²⁺ influx. Ca²⁺ influx is triggered by the arriving impulse, not the other way around. The sequence always begins with the arrival of the nerve impulse.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Myelinated nerve fibres conduct impulses faster than non-myelinated fibres.
Reason: In myelinated fibres, the impulse undergoes saltatory conduction, jumping from node to node.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not correctly explain the assertion
The assertion is true, but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true. Myelinated fibres conduct impulses much faster (up to 120 m/s) than non-myelinated fibres (0.5-2 m/s). This is because the myelin sheath insulates the axon, and the impulse jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next (saltatory conduction), which is the reason for the faster speed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true — myelinated fibres are demonstrably faster. The reason (saltatory conduction) is the correct explanation for this increased speed. Therefore, both are true and the reason explains the assertion.

questions.question_text: A neuron that carries impulses from the CNS to an effector organ is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Motor (efferent) neurons carry impulses from the CNS to effector organs such as muscles and glands. The term 'efferent' means carrying away from the centre. Motor neurons are typically multipolar in structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sensory (afferent) neurons carry impulses from receptors towards the CNS. Interneurons are found within the CNS and connect sensory and motor neurons. Unipolar refers to structural classification (one process from the cell body), not functional classification.

questions.question_text: Which neurotransmitter is released at the cholinergic synapse?
questions.explanation_correct: Acetylcholine is the neurotransmitter released at cholinergic synapses. These include the neuromuscular junction, preganglionic fibres of the autonomic nervous system, and postganglionic parasympathetic fibres. Acetylcholine is broken down by acetylcholinesterase in the synaptic cleft.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dopamine is released at dopaminergic synapses (involved in reward and motor control). Noradrenaline is released at adrenergic synapses (sympathetic postganglionic fibres). GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. Cholinergic specifically refers to acetylcholine.

questions.question_text: The enzyme that breaks down acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft is:
questions.explanation_correct: Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) is the enzyme present in the synaptic cleft that rapidly hydrolyses acetylcholine into choline and acetate. This terminates the signal transmission and prevents continuous stimulation of the postsynaptic membrane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monoamine oxidase breaks down monoamine neurotransmitters (dopamine, noradrenaline, serotonin). ATPase hydrolyses ATP. Lipase digests fats. Acetylcholinesterase is the specific enzyme for acetylcholine breakdown.

questions.question_text: Neurons that transmit impulses from sensory receptors to the CNS are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Afferent (sensory) neurons carry nerve impulses from sensory receptors (in skin, eyes, ears, etc.) towards the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord). The term 'afferent' means carrying towards the centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Efferent neurons (motor neurons) carry impulses from the CNS to effectors. Interneurons are located within the CNS and act as relay neurons. Motor neurons transmit signals to muscles and glands.

questions.question_text: The largest part of the human brain is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The cerebrum is the largest part of the human brain, constituting about two-thirds of the brain's total mass. It is divided into left and right hemispheres connected by the corpus callosum. The cerebral cortex is responsible for thinking, memory, reasoning, speech, and voluntary actions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebellum is the second largest part of the brain, located behind the brain stem. The medulla oblongata is a small region in the hindbrain. The hypothalamus is a small structure in the diencephalon.

questions.question_text: The part of the brain that controls involuntary functions such as respiration, cardiovascular reflexes, and gastric secretions is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The medulla oblongata, located in the hindbrain, contains vital centres that control involuntary functions including respiration, heart rate, blood pressure, swallowing, coughing, sneezing, and vomiting. It is often called the 'vital knot'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebrum controls voluntary actions and higher mental functions. The cerebellum coordinates voluntary movements and maintains posture and balance. The thalamus relays sensory information to the cerebral cortex.

questions.question_text: The brain and spinal cord are covered by protective membranes called:
questions.explanation_correct: The meninges are three protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord: the outer dura mater (tough and fibrous), the middle arachnoid mater, and the inner pia mater (delicate, closely applied to the brain surface). CSF fills the space between the arachnoid and pia mater.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Periosteum covers bones. Pleura covers the lungs. Pericardium covers the heart. The membranes specifically covering the CNS are called meninges.

questions.question_text: Which part of the brain coordinates voluntary movements and maintains body posture and equilibrium?
questions.explanation_correct: The cerebellum, located at the back of the brain below the cerebrum, is responsible for coordinating voluntary muscular movements, maintaining body posture, balance, and equilibrium. Damage to the cerebellum results in uncoordinated and jerky movements (ataxia).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebrum initiates voluntary movements but does not coordinate them. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature, hunger, thirst, and emotions. The pons serves as a relay station between the cerebrum and cerebellum.

questions.question_text: The hypothalamus is part of the:
questions.explanation_correct: The hypothalamus is a part of the diencephalon in the forebrain. It lies below the thalamus and controls body temperature, hunger, thirst, fatigue, sleep, circadian rhythms, and emotional behaviour. It also links the nervous system to the endocrine system via the pituitary gland.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The midbrain is located between the forebrain and hindbrain and contains visual and auditory reflex centres. The hindbrain includes the cerebellum, pons, and medulla. The spinal cord extends from the medulla through the vertebral column.

questions.question_text: The corpus callosum connects:

options.text: The left and right cerebral hemispheres

questions.explanation_correct: The corpus callosum is a thick band of nerve fibres (white matter) that connects the left and right cerebral hemispheres, allowing communication and coordination between them. It is the largest white matter structure in the brain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebrum and cerebellum are connected via the pons and brain stem, not the corpus callosum. The brain and spinal cord are connected via the medulla oblongata. The thalamus and hypothalamus are separate structures in the diencephalon.

questions.question_text: Which lobe of the cerebrum is associated with the visual area?
questions.explanation_correct: The occipital lobe, located at the back of the cerebrum, contains the primary visual cortex. It receives and processes visual information from the eyes via the optic nerves and thalamus. Damage to this area can cause visual impairment or blindness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The frontal lobe contains the motor area and is associated with reasoning, planning, and speech. The parietal lobe contains the sensory area for touch, pressure, and temperature. The temporal lobe contains the auditory area.

questions.question_text: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is produced by the:
questions.explanation_correct: CSF is produced by the choroid plexus, a network of capillaries located in the ventricles of the brain. CSF fills the ventricles and the subarachnoid space, providing cushioning, buoyancy, and a stable chemical environment for the brain and spinal cord.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Meninges are protective membranes but do not produce CSF. The cerebellum is a brain region. Spinal nerves are part of the PNS. CSF is specifically secreted by the choroid plexus.

questions.question_text:
Match the following brain parts with their functions:

(i) Cerebrum    (P) Coordination of movements, balance
(ii) Cerebellum    (Q) Control of breathing, heart rate
(iii) Medulla oblongata    (R) Thinking, memory, reasoning
(iv) Hypothalamus    (S) Body temperature regulation, hunger, thirst

Select the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Cerebrum (R) — responsible for higher mental functions like thinking, memory, and reasoning. Cerebellum (P) — coordinates voluntary movements and maintains balance. Medulla oblongata (Q) — controls vital involuntary functions like breathing and heart rate. Hypothalamus (S) — regulates body temperature, hunger, and thirst.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each brain part has a specific primary function. The cerebrum handles higher cognition, the cerebellum handles coordination, the medulla handles vital reflexes, and the hypothalamus handles homeostatic regulation.

questions.question_text: In the spinal cord, the grey matter is located:
questions.explanation_correct: In the spinal cord, the grey matter (containing cell bodies and dendrites) is located centrally, forming a butterfly or H-shaped region. The white matter (containing myelinated nerve fibres) surrounds the grey matter on the outside. This is opposite to the arrangement in the cerebrum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The outer surface of the spinal cord has white matter, not grey matter. Grey matter is not limited to the dorsal horn — it includes both dorsal and ventral horns. It does not occupy the entire cross-section; it is restricted to the central region.

questions.question_text: Which part of the brain serves as a relay centre for sensory information before it reaches the cerebral cortex?
questions.explanation_correct: The thalamus acts as the major relay station for sensory information (except olfaction) travelling to the cerebral cortex. It receives sensory signals from the eyes, ears, skin, and other receptors, processes them, and forwards them to the appropriate cortical areas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The hypothalamus regulates homeostatic functions and does not serve as a general sensory relay. The medulla controls vital reflexes. The cerebellum coordinates movement. The thalamus is specifically the sensory relay centre.

questions.question_text: A person suffers damage to the cerebellum. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to occur?
questions.explanation_correct: Damage to the cerebellum results in ataxia — loss of muscle coordination, unsteady gait, difficulty with fine motor tasks, and impaired balance and equilibrium. The cerebellum does not initiate movements but fine-tunes them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Memory loss would result from damage to the cerebrum (hippocampus). Temperature regulation is controlled by the hypothalamus. Breathing is controlled by the medulla oblongata. Cerebellar damage specifically affects coordination and balance.

questions.question_text: A reflex arc consists of the following components in the correct order:

options.text: Effector → Motor neuron → CNS → Sensory neuron → Receptor
Receptor → Sensory neuron → CNS → Motor neuron → Effector
Receptor → Motor neuron → CNS → Sensory neuron → Effector
CNS → Sensory neuron → Receptor → Motor neuron → Effector

questions.explanation_correct: A reflex arc follows the sequence: receptor (detects stimulus) → sensory (afferent) neuron → CNS (spinal cord or brain, where integration occurs) → motor (efferent) neuron → effector (muscle or gland that responds). This is the pathway for a reflex action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The receptor must detect the stimulus first, so the arc begins with the receptor. Sensory neurons carry information to the CNS, and motor neurons carry responses to effectors. The sequence is always receptor → sensory → CNS → motor → effector.

questions.question_text: The autonomic nervous system is divided into:
questions.explanation_correct: The autonomic nervous system (ANS) is divided into the sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions. The sympathetic division prepares the body for 'fight or flight' responses (increases heart rate, dilates pupils). The parasympathetic division promotes 'rest and digest' activities (decreases heart rate, stimulates digestion).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The PNS is divided into somatic and autonomic divisions. Sensory and motor are functional classifications of neurons. Cranial and spinal refer to types of nerves. The ANS specifically has sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions.

questions.question_text: The photoreceptor cells in the human retina that are responsible for vision in dim light are:
questions.explanation_correct: Rods are photoreceptor cells that contain the photopigment rhodopsin (formed from scotopsin + retinal, a derivative of vitamin A). They are highly sensitive to light and function primarily in dim light (scotopic vision) but cannot distinguish colours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cones function in bright light and are responsible for colour vision (photopic vision). Bipolar cells are neurons that connect rods and cones to ganglion cells. Ganglion cells transmit visual information from the retina to the brain via the optic nerve.

questions.question_text: The part of the ear responsible for maintaining body balance is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The three semicircular canals, along with the utricle and saccule (collectively called the vestibular apparatus), are responsible for maintaining body balance and equilibrium. They detect rotational movements of the head and body position in space.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cochlea is involved in hearing, not balance. The Eustachian tube equalises pressure between the middle ear and the atmosphere. The tympanic membrane (eardrum) vibrates in response to sound waves.

questions.question_text: When you accidentally touch a hot object, your hand withdraws even before you feel the pain. This is because:

options.text: The brain processes the information first and sends a command
The reflex arc through the spinal cord mediates the withdrawal before the brain registers the sensation
Pain receptors in the hand directly stimulate the muscles
The sympathetic nervous system causes immediate muscle contraction

questions.explanation_correct: This is a spinal reflex. The sensory neuron from the pain receptor transmits the impulse to the spinal cord, where an interneuron connects it to a motor neuron that causes the hand muscles to contract and withdraw. This occurs before the impulse reaches the brain for conscious perception of pain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is not involved in the initial withdrawal — the reflex is mediated at the spinal cord level. Pain receptors do not directly stimulate muscles. The sympathetic nervous system is not responsible for this specific withdrawal reflex.

questions.question_text: The region of the retina where the optic nerve leaves the eye, and which has no photoreceptor cells, is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The blind spot (optic disc) is the point on the retina where the optic nerve fibres exit the eye. This area lacks rods and cones, so no image is formed here. It is a natural gap in the visual field that the brain compensates for.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fovea centralis (yellow spot or macula lutea) is the area of sharpest vision with the highest density of cones. The iris is the coloured muscular diaphragm that controls pupil size. The blind spot specifically refers to the optic disc.

questions.question_text: The three small bones (ossicles) in the middle ear, in order from the tympanic membrane to the oval window, are:
questions.explanation_correct: The three ear ossicles in order from the tympanic membrane to the oval window are: malleus (hammer, attached to the eardrum), incus (anvil, connects malleus and stapes), and stapes (stirrup, the smallest bone, attached to the oval window of the cochlea). They amplify and transmit sound vibrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The malleus is always closest to the tympanic membrane, followed by the incus, and then the stapes at the oval window. Any other sequence is anatomically incorrect.

questions.question_text: The organ of Corti, which is the receptor organ for hearing, is located in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The organ of Corti is located on the basilar membrane within the cochlea of the inner ear. It contains specialised hair cells that convert sound vibrations into nerve impulses. These impulses are transmitted to the brain via the auditory nerve (vestibulocochlear nerve).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The external ear (pinna, ear canal) collects sound waves. The middle ear contains the three ossicles. The semicircular canals are involved in balance, not hearing. The organ of Corti is specifically in the cochlea.

questions.question_text: Myopia (short-sightedness) is corrected by using:
questions.explanation_correct: Myopia occurs when the eyeball is too long or the lens is too curved, causing distant images to focus in front of the retina. A concave (diverging) lens is used to correct this by diverging light rays before they enter the eye, shifting the focal point back onto the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A convex lens corrects hypermetropia (long-sightedness), not myopia. A cylindrical lens corrects astigmatism. Bifocal lenses are used for presbyopia. Myopia specifically requires a concave lens.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the human eye is correct?

options.text: The fovea is the blind spot of the retina
Rods are concentrated at the fovea and are responsible for colour vision
The fovea has the highest concentration of cones and is the area of sharpest vision
The iris controls the shape of the lens for accommodation

questions.explanation_correct: The fovea centralis (located at the centre of the macula lutea or yellow spot) has the highest density of cone photoreceptors and no rods. It is the point of sharpest and most detailed vision. When we focus on an object, its image falls on the fovea.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fovea is not the blind spot — the blind spot is where the optic nerve exits. Rods are more concentrated in the peripheral retina, not the fovea, and they do not detect colour. The ciliary muscles (not the iris) control the shape of the lens for accommodation.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: The sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions of the autonomic nervous system have opposite effects on most organs.
Reason: The sympathetic system prepares the body for emergencies while the parasympathetic system promotes maintenance activities.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not correctly explain the assertion
The assertion is true, but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. The sympathetic and parasympathetic systems generally have antagonistic effects: for example, the sympathetic system increases heart rate while the parasympathetic decreases it. This is because the sympathetic system prepares the body for 'fight or flight' while the parasympathetic promotes 'rest and digest', which directly explains their opposing effects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true — they do have opposite effects on most organs. The reason accurately describes why: their different functional roles (emergency vs. maintenance) lead to antagonistic effects. Both are true and the reason explains the assertion.

questions.question_text: The photopigment rhodopsin is composed of:

options.text: Scotopsin (opsin protein) and retinal (aldehyde of vitamin A)

questions.explanation_correct: Rhodopsin is the photopigment found in rod cells. It consists of a protein called scotopsin (opsin) and a light-absorbing group called retinal (11-cis-retinal), which is an aldehyde derivative of vitamin A. When light hits rhodopsin, retinal changes from cis to trans form, triggering a nerve impulse.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iodopsin is the photopigment in cone cells, not rhodopsin. Melanin is a skin pigment. Haemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein in RBCs. Rhodopsin is specifically composed of scotopsin and retinal.

questions.question_text: The function of the Eustachian tube is to:

options.text: Transmit sound vibrations to the cochlea
Equalise air pressure on both sides of the tympanic membrane
Produce endolymph for the inner ear
Connect the inner ear to the brain

questions.explanation_correct: The Eustachian tube (auditory tube or pharyngotympanic tube) connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx. Its primary function is to equalise the air pressure on both sides of the tympanic membrane, which is essential for proper vibration of the eardrum and normal hearing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound vibrations are transmitted by the ear ossicles (malleus, incus, stapes), not the Eustachian tube. Endolymph is produced within the inner ear. The auditory nerve connects the inner ear to the brain. The Eustachian tube specifically serves pressure equalisation.

questions.question_text: The limbic system, which is associated with emotions and motivation, includes the:
questions.explanation_correct: The limbic system includes structures such as the hippocampus (involved in memory formation), amygdala (involved in emotions, especially fear and aggression), hypothalamus, and parts of the thalamus. It plays a key role in emotional responses, memory, and motivation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebellum and pons are part of the hindbrain and are not limbic structures. The medulla and midbrain have distinct functions. The spinal cord and cranial nerves are not part of the limbic system.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes accommodation in the human eye?

options.text: Change in pupil size by the iris
Change in the curvature of the lens by ciliary muscles to focus on objects at different distances
Movement of the eyeball by extraocular muscles
Change in the sensitivity of rod cells in different light conditions

questions.explanation_correct: Accommodation is the ability of the eye to adjust the curvature of the lens to focus on objects at different distances. The ciliary muscles contract to make the lens more convex (for near objects) or relax to flatten the lens (for distant objects).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Change in pupil size is called pupillary reflex, not accommodation. Eyeball movement is controlled by extraocular muscles but is not accommodation. Change in rod sensitivity relates to dark/light adaptation, not accommodation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about the synaptic cleft?

options.text: It is filled with cytoplasm connecting two neurons
It is a gap between the axon terminal of one neuron and the dendrite or cell body of the next neuron
It allows direct flow of electrical current between neurons
It is found only in the PNS, not in the CNS

questions.explanation_correct: The synaptic cleft is a narrow fluid-filled gap (about 20-40 nm wide) between the presynaptic membrane (axon terminal) and the postsynaptic membrane (dendrite or cell body of the next neuron). Neurotransmitters diffuse across this gap to transmit the signal chemically.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The synaptic cleft is not filled with cytoplasm — it is an extracellular space. Chemical synapses do not allow direct electrical current flow (that occurs in electrical synapses via gap junctions). Synapses are found throughout both the CNS and PNS.

questions.question_text: The cranial nerve that carries visual impulses from the retina to the brain is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The optic nerve (cranial nerve II) is a sensory nerve that transmits visual information from the retina to the brain (specifically to the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus and then to the visual cortex in the occipital lobe).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The olfactory nerve (I) carries smell sensations. The vagus nerve (X) is the longest cranial nerve and supplies thoracic and abdominal organs. The auditory nerve (VIII, vestibulocochlear) carries hearing and balance information. Visual impulses are transmitted by the optic nerve.

questions.question_text: Hypermetropia (long-sightedness) can be corrected using a:
questions.explanation_correct: Hypermetropia occurs when the eyeball is too short or the lens is too flat, causing near objects to focus behind the retina. A convex (converging) lens is used to correct this by converging light rays before they enter the eye, bringing the focal point forward onto the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave lens is used to correct myopia, not hypermetropia. A cylindrical lens corrects astigmatism. A plano-convex lens is not the standard corrective lens for this condition. Hypermetropia requires a convex lens.

questions.question_text: The coloured part of the eye that controls the size of the pupil is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The iris is the coloured, muscular diaphragm that lies between the cornea and the lens. It controls the size of the pupil (the central aperture) by contracting or relaxing its circular and radial muscles, thereby regulating the amount of light entering the eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea is the transparent front part of the eye. The sclera is the white, opaque outer coat. The retina is the light-sensitive inner layer. The iris is the specific structure responsible for pupil size control.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a function of the pons?

options.text: It serves as a relay centre connecting the cerebrum to the cerebellum

questions.explanation_correct: The pons (meaning 'bridge') is located in the hindbrain between the midbrain and the medulla oblongata. Its primary function is to relay signals between the cerebrum and the cerebellum. It also contains nuclei involved in regulation of respiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Body temperature control is a function of the hypothalamus. Heart rate control is primarily managed by the medulla oblongata. CSF is produced by the choroid plexus in the ventricles. The pons specifically acts as a relay bridge.

questions.question_text: In the peripheral nervous system, the myelin sheath around nerve fibres is formed by:
questions.explanation_correct: In the peripheral nervous system (PNS), the myelin sheath is formed by Schwann cells (neurolemmocytes). Each Schwann cell wraps around a segment of a single axon. In the central nervous system (CNS), oligodendrocytes form the myelin sheath.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oligodendrocytes form myelin in the CNS, not the PNS. Astrocytes provide structural support and nutrition in the CNS. Microglia are phagocytic immune cells of the CNS. Schwann cells are the PNS-specific myelinating cells.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following pairs of eye defects and their corrective lenses is correctly matched?

(i) Myopia — Concave lens
(ii) Hypermetropia — Convex lens
(iii) Astigmatism — Cylindrical lens
questions.explanation_correct: All three matchings are correct. Myopia (short-sightedness) is corrected with a concave (diverging) lens. Hypermetropia (long-sightedness) is corrected with a convex (converging) lens. Astigmatism (uneven curvature of the cornea or lens) is corrected with a cylindrical lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each of the three matchings is individually correct. Myopia — concave, hypermetropia — convex, and astigmatism — cylindrical are all standard optical corrections taught in biology and physics.

questions.question_text: How does saltatory conduction in myelinated nerve fibres differ from continuous conduction in non-myelinated nerve fibres in terms of impulse propagation?

options.text: Saltatory conduction involves continuous depolarisation along the entire axon, whereas continuous conduction involves jumping between nodes
Saltatory conduction involves the impulse jumping from node to node, whereas continuous conduction involves sequential depolarisation along the entire axon membrane
Both use the same mechanism but saltatory conduction uses more ATP
Saltatory conduction occurs only in the CNS while continuous conduction occurs only in the PNS

questions.explanation_correct: In saltatory conduction, the action potential jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next because the myelin sheath insulates the internodal regions, making conduction much faster (up to 120 m/s). In non-myelinated fibres, depolarisation occurs sequentially along the entire length of the axon membrane (continuous conduction), which is slower (0.5-2 m/s) and uses more energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The descriptions in option A are reversed. Saltatory conduction is actually more energy-efficient, not less, because fewer Na⁺/K⁺ pumps need to be activated. Both types of conduction can occur in the CNS and PNS.

questions.question_text: How does the arrangement of grey and white matter in the cerebrum differ from that in the spinal cord?

options.text: In both, grey matter is on the outside and white matter is on the inside
In the cerebrum, grey matter forms the outer cortex and white matter is internal; in the spinal cord, grey matter is internal (H-shaped) and white matter is external
In the cerebrum, white matter forms the cortex; in the spinal cord, grey matter forms the cortex
There is no difference — both have grey matter on the inside

questions.explanation_correct: In the cerebrum, grey matter (cell bodies, dendrites) forms the outer cerebral cortex, while white matter (myelinated axons) lies internally. This arrangement is reversed in the spinal cord, where grey matter forms an internal H-shaped or butterfly-shaped region surrounded by external white matter. This reversal is an important anatomical distinction tested in CBSE and NEET exams.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The arrangement is opposite in the two structures, so options stating they are the same are incorrect. The cerebral cortex is grey matter, not white matter.

questions.question_text: How do rods differ from cones in the human retina with respect to their photopigments?

options.text: Rods contain iodopsin while cones contain rhodopsin
Rods contain rhodopsin (scotopsin + retinal) while cones contain iodopsin (photopsin + retinal)
Both rods and cones contain rhodopsin but in different concentrations
Rods lack any photopigment while cones contain melanopsin

questions.explanation_correct: Rods contain the photopigment rhodopsin, which is composed of the protein scotopsin (opsin) and the chromophore retinal (11-cis-retinal, a derivative of vitamin A). Cones contain iodopsin, composed of the protein photopsin and retinal. Rhodopsin is highly sensitive to dim light, while iodopsin functions in bright light and enables colour vision.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the photopigments. Rods and cones contain different photopigments, not the same one. Rods certainly contain a photopigment (rhodopsin), and melanopsin is found in intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells, not in cones.

questions.question_text: How does the sympathetic nervous system differ from the parasympathetic nervous system in its effect on heart rate?

options.text: The sympathetic system decreases heart rate while the parasympathetic system increases it
Both systems increase heart rate but through different neurotransmitters
The sympathetic system increases heart rate (via noradrenaline) while the parasympathetic system decreases heart rate (via acetylcholine)
Neither system directly affects heart rate; it is controlled solely by the medulla

questions.explanation_correct: The sympathetic nervous system releases noradrenaline at the cardiac plexus, which increases heart rate and force of contraction (positive chronotropic and inotropic effect). The parasympathetic system, through the vagus nerve, releases acetylcholine, which decreases heart rate (negative chronotropic effect). This antagonistic dual control allows precise regulation of cardiac function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the effects. Both systems do not increase heart rate — they have antagonistic effects. The autonomic nervous system (both sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions) directly innervates the heart and affects its rate; the medulla coordinates this but the ANS mediates the effect.

questions.question_text: How does a chemical synapse differ from an electrical synapse in terms of signal transmission?

options.text: A chemical synapse uses neurotransmitters to cross the synaptic cleft, whereas an electrical synapse uses gap junctions for direct ionic current flow between neurons
A chemical synapse uses gap junctions while an electrical synapse uses neurotransmitters
Both use neurotransmitters but chemical synapses are faster
Chemical synapses allow bidirectional transmission while electrical synapses are unidirectional

questions.explanation_correct: At a chemical synapse, the presynaptic neuron releases neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft; these bind to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane to generate a new impulse. This introduces a slight synaptic delay. At an electrical synapse, gap junctions directly connect the cytoplasm of adjacent neurons, allowing rapid bidirectional flow of ions and electrical current with virtually no delay.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B reverses the descriptions. Chemical synapses are actually slower than electrical synapses due to the time required for neurotransmitter release and diffusion. Chemical synapses are typically unidirectional, while electrical synapses are usually bidirectional.

questions.question_text: A neuron has a single, long process extending from the cell body that branches into a peripheral process (towards the receptor) and a central process (towards the CNS). This neuron is structurally classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: A unipolar (more precisely pseudounipolar) neuron has a single process extending from the cell body that splits into two branches — a peripheral process going to the receptor and a central process going to the CNS. Most sensory neurons in the dorsal root ganglia of spinal nerves are pseudounipolar.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A multipolar neuron has one axon and multiple dendrites. A bipolar neuron has one axon and one dendrite, each extending from opposite ends of the cell body. Interneuron is a functional classification, not a structural one. The description of a single branching process fits the unipolar (pseudounipolar) type.

questions.question_text: A brain region is known to regulate body temperature, hunger, thirst, and circadian rhythms, and serves as the link between the nervous system and the endocrine system via the pituitary gland. This region is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The hypothalamus is the control centre for body temperature, hunger, thirst, fatigue, sleep, and circadian rhythms. Crucially, it links the neural system to the endocrine system by controlling the pituitary gland (the 'master gland'). It is part of the diencephalon in the forebrain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The thalamus is a sensory relay centre and does not regulate temperature or hunger. The cerebellum coordinates voluntary movement and balance. The medulla oblongata controls vital involuntary functions like breathing and heart rate. Only the hypothalamus fits all the described functions.

questions.question_text: A structure in the inner ear rests on the basilar membrane, contains specialised hair cells, and converts sound vibrations into nerve impulses. This structure is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The organ of Corti is the sensory receptor organ for hearing, located on the basilar membrane inside the cochlea. It contains rows of inner and outer hair cells whose stereocilia are deflected by vibrations in the endolymph, triggering nerve impulses that travel via the auditory nerve to the brain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The semicircular canals detect rotational movements and are involved in balance, not hearing. The vestibular apparatus (utricle, saccule, semicircular canals) maintains equilibrium. The tympanic membrane is in the middle ear and vibrates in response to sound but does not convert vibrations to nerve impulses.

questions.question_text: A brain structure is located in the hindbrain, acts as a bridge relaying signals between the cerebrum and the cerebellum, and also contains nuclei involved in regulation of respiration. This structure is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The pons (Latin for 'bridge') is located in the hindbrain between the midbrain and the medulla oblongata. Its primary role is to relay signals between the cerebrum and the cerebellum. It also contains pneumotaxic and apneustic centres that help regulate breathing by modulating the respiratory rhythm generated by the medulla.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The medulla oblongata controls vital involuntary reflexes but is not described as a bridge between cerebrum and cerebellum. The midbrain is part of the brainstem but lies above the pons. The thalamus is in the forebrain (diencephalon), not the hindbrain.

questions.question_text: Riya, a 17-year-old student, visits an ophthalmologist complaining that she cannot read her textbook clearly when held at normal reading distance, but can see the classroom blackboard without difficulty. The doctor determines that the image of near objects is forming behind her retina. Which condition does Riya most likely have, and what corrective lens would be prescribed?

options.text: Myopia; corrected with a concave lens
Hypermetropia; corrected with a convex lens
Astigmatism; corrected with a cylindrical lens
Presbyopia; corrected with a concave lens

questions.explanation_correct: Riya's symptoms — difficulty seeing near objects while distant vision is normal, with the image forming behind the retina — are characteristic of hypermetropia (long-sightedness). This occurs when the eyeball is too short or the lens is insufficiently convex. A convex (converging) lens brings the focal point forward onto the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Myopia involves difficulty seeing distant objects (image forms in front of retina), which is the opposite of Riya's symptoms. Astigmatism causes blurred vision at all distances due to uneven corneal curvature. Presbyopia involves age-related loss of accommodation (typically after age 40) and is corrected with convex lenses, not concave.

questions.question_text: Amit, a 45-year-old man, is brought to a neurology clinic after a road accident. His MRI scan reveals significant damage to the cerebellum. Based on this finding, which of the following symptoms would the neurologist most likely observe during clinical examination?

options.text: Amit cannot recall his name or recognise family members
Amit's breathing rate has become dangerously irregular
Amit shows an unsteady gait, difficulty touching his nose with his finger, and poor balance while standing
Amit has completely lost his ability to feel pain and temperature

questions.explanation_correct: The cerebellum is responsible for coordinating voluntary movements, maintaining posture, balance, and equilibrium. Damage to the cerebellum results in ataxia — an unsteady gait, inability to perform coordinated movements (like the finger-to-nose test), tremor during voluntary movements, and poor balance. These are classic cerebellar signs tested in clinical neurology.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Memory loss and inability to recognise people would result from damage to the cerebrum (specifically the hippocampus and temporal cortex). Irregular breathing would be caused by medulla oblongata damage. Loss of pain and temperature sensation would involve damage to the sensory cortex (parietal lobe) or the thalamus.

questions.question_text: In a school biology lab, Priya is studying the effect of a drug on synaptic transmission. The drug blocks the enzyme acetylcholinesterase at the neuromuscular junction. What effect would Priya observe on the postsynaptic muscle cell?

options.text: The muscle would not contract at all because no neurotransmitter is released
The muscle would undergo sustained contraction (spasm) because acetylcholine is not broken down and continuously stimulates the receptors
The muscle would relax completely because the drug enhances repolarisation
The muscle would show no change because acetylcholinesterase is not involved in muscle contraction

questions.explanation_correct: Acetylcholinesterase normally breaks down acetylcholine (ACh) in the synaptic cleft, terminating the signal. If this enzyme is blocked, ACh accumulates and continues to bind to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane, causing prolonged depolarisation and sustained muscle contraction (spasm or tetany). This is the mechanism by which organophosphate pesticides and nerve agents cause toxicity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The drug does not prevent ACh release — it prevents ACh breakdown. With continuous receptor stimulation, the muscle contracts, it does not relax. Acetylcholinesterase is crucial for terminating neuromuscular transmission, so blocking it has a profound effect.

questions.question_text: Rohan, a 16-year-old student, experiences a sudden loud sound during a Diwali celebration. He notices that his heart rate increases, his pupils dilate, and his mouth feels dry. A biology teacher explains that these responses are mediated by a specific division of the nervous system. Which division is responsible for these 'fight or flight' responses?
questions.explanation_correct: The sympathetic nervous system mediates the 'fight or flight' response during stressful or emergency situations. Its effects include increased heart rate, pupil dilation (mydriasis), reduced salivation (dry mouth), bronchodilation, and redirection of blood flow to skeletal muscles. All of Rohan's symptoms are classic sympathetic responses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The parasympathetic system promotes 'rest and digest' responses — it would decrease heart rate and constrict pupils. The somatic nervous system controls voluntary skeletal muscle movement. The CNS (brain and spinal cord) processes information but the autonomic sympathetic division specifically mediates these involuntary stress responses.

questions.question_text: Meera, a medical student, is studying a brain specimen. She notices that a specific region in the forebrain receives sensory information from all sense organs (except olfactory input) and relays it to the appropriate areas of the cerebral cortex. Which structure is Meera examining?
questions.explanation_correct: The thalamus, located in the diencephalon of the forebrain, is the major relay station for all sensory information (except olfaction) before it reaches the cerebral cortex. Visual signals from the retina, auditory signals from the cochlea, and somatosensory signals all pass through thalamic nuclei before being projected to their respective cortical areas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The hypothalamus regulates homeostatic functions and neuroendocrine activity, not sensory relay. The corpus callosum connects the two cerebral hemispheres. The pons is in the hindbrain and relays signals between the cerebrum and cerebellum. Only the thalamus serves as the general sensory relay centre.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a part of the neuron?
questions.explanation_correct: A sarcomere is the basic contractile unit of a skeletal muscle fibre (myofibril), bounded by Z-lines. It is not a part of a neuron. The three main structural parts of a neuron are the cell body (soma), dendrites, and the axon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dendrites are branched cytoplasmic extensions that receive impulses. The axon is the long fibre that conducts impulses away from the cell body. The cell body (soma) contains the nucleus and Nissl granules. All three are genuine parts of a neuron; only the sarcomere belongs to muscle tissue.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a function of the medulla oblongata?

options.text: Coordination of voluntary movements and maintenance of balance
Control of swallowing and vomiting reflexes

questions.explanation_correct: Coordination of voluntary movements and maintenance of balance are functions of the cerebellum, not the medulla oblongata. The medulla oblongata controls vital involuntary functions including heart rate, respiration, blood pressure, and reflexes like swallowing, coughing, sneezing, and vomiting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Regulation of heart rate, control of respiration, and control of swallowing and vomiting reflexes are all genuine functions of the medulla oblongata. The coordination of voluntary movements and balance is performed by the cerebellum.

questions.question_text: Which of the following sensory inputs is NOT relayed through the thalamus before reaching the cerebral cortex?

options.text: Olfactory information from the nasal epithelium

questions.explanation_correct: Olfactory (smell) information is the only major sensory modality that does not pass through the thalamus before reaching the cerebral cortex. Olfactory signals travel from the olfactory epithelium to the olfactory bulb and then directly to the olfactory cortex and limbic system. Visual, auditory, and somatosensory inputs all relay through specific thalamic nuclei before reaching their respective cortical areas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Visual information passes through the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus. Auditory information passes through the medial geniculate nucleus. Somatosensory information passes through the ventral posterior nucleus. Only olfactory input bypasses the thalamus.

questions.question_text: Why is synaptic transmission at a chemical synapse described as unidirectional (from presynaptic to postsynaptic neuron only)?

options.text: Because the postsynaptic neuron is always larger than the presynaptic neuron
Because neurotransmitter vesicles are present only in the presynaptic terminal and receptors are present only on the postsynaptic membrane
Because the synaptic cleft is too narrow for reverse diffusion
Because action potentials can only travel in one direction along any axon

questions.explanation_correct: Chemical synaptic transmission is unidirectional because of the asymmetric distribution of key components: synaptic vesicles containing neurotransmitter are located only in the presynaptic terminal, and specific receptors for that neurotransmitter are concentrated on the postsynaptic membrane. The postsynaptic terminal cannot release neurotransmitter back across the cleft, and the presynaptic terminal lacks the appropriate receptors, ensuring one-way signal flow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neuron size has nothing to do with the directionality of transmission. The synaptic cleft width does not prevent reverse diffusion — the issue is the absence of vesicles on the postsynaptic side and receptors on the presynaptic side. An action potential can theoretically travel in both directions along an axon; it is the synapse that enforces unidirectionality.

questions.question_text: Why is the hypothalamus considered the primary link between the nervous system and the endocrine system?

options.text: Because the hypothalamus directly secretes all hormones into the blood
Because the hypothalamus produces releasing and inhibiting hormones that regulate the anterior pituitary, and also sends neural signals to the posterior pituitary to release hormones
Because the hypothalamus is the largest structure in the brain
Because the hypothalamus contains the highest density of sensory neurons in the brain

questions.explanation_correct: The hypothalamus links the nervous and endocrine systems through two mechanisms: (1) it produces releasing hormones (e.g., GnRH, TRH, CRH) and inhibiting hormones (e.g., somatostatin) that regulate hormone secretion by the anterior pituitary via the hypothalamo-hypophysial portal system, and (2) it has neurosecretory cells whose axons extend to the posterior pituitary, where they release oxytocin and vasopressin (ADH) directly into the blood. This dual neurosecretory role makes it the primary neuroendocrine integrator.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The hypothalamus does not directly secrete all hormones — it regulates the pituitary, which in turn controls other endocrine glands. The hypothalamus is actually a small structure, not the largest. Sensory neuron density is not the reason for its neuroendocrine role.

questions.question_text: Why does a spinal reflex (such as the knee-jerk reflex) occur faster than a voluntary response to the same stimulus?

options.text: Because reflex arcs use thicker neurons that always conduct impulses faster
Because the reflex arc involves integration at the spinal cord level without waiting for the impulse to travel to the brain for conscious processing
Because reflex arcs do not involve any synapses
Because the effector muscles in reflexes contract without requiring a motor neuron

questions.explanation_correct: Spinal reflexes are faster because the sensory impulse needs to travel only to the spinal cord, where it is directly relayed (often through just one interneuron) to a motor neuron that activates the effector. The impulse does not need to travel the much longer distance to the brain for conscious processing and decision-making. The shorter neural pathway and minimal synaptic relays result in a much faster response time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neuron thickness may vary but is not the primary reason for the speed difference. Reflex arcs do involve synapses (at minimum, a sensory-motor synapse). Motor neurons are always required to stimulate effectors — muscles cannot contract without neural input.
